title: How to learn Go
description: Go is a statically typed, compiled programming language designed at Google by Robert Griesemer, Rob Pike, and Ken Thompson. Go is syntactically similar to C, but with memory safety, garbage collection, structural typing, and CSP-style concurrency. The language is often referred to as Golang because of its domain name, golang.org, but the proper name is Go. Go was designed to address criticisms of other languages in use at Google while keeping the useful characteristics of those languages. Go was designed to be simple, efficient, and easy to use. Go's concurrency features make it easy to write programs that get the most out of multicore and networked machines. Go's garbage collection makes it easy to write programs that don't have memory leaks. Go's standard library provides a rich set of built-in types and functions. Go is a compiled language, which means that Go code is compiled into machine code that can be executed directly by the computer. Go is also a garbage-collected language, which means that Go automatically manages memory for you. Go is designed to be simple and easy to use, with a focus on readability and maintainability. Go's syntax is clean and concise, and Go's standard library is comprehensive and well-documented. Go is used for a wide range of applications, including web development, cloud computing, microservices, and more. Companies like Google, Uber, Dropbox, and Docker use Go in production. Go has a growing ecosystem of libraries and tools, and its package manager, Go Modules, makes it easy to manage dependencies and build projects.
